description: Shortened form of any of various words beginning with sub-.

entries.meaning: A submarine sandwich: a sandwich made on a long bun.
examples: We can get subs at that deli.

entries.meaning: (informal) A substitute, often in sports or teaching.
examples: With the score 4 to 1, they brought in subs.
She worked as a sub until she got her teaching certificate.

entries.meaning: (Britain, informal, often in plural) A subscription: a payment made for membership of a club, etc.
examples: According to the best available information, GALAXY has several times as many subs as any other science fiction magazine!
I've just noticed a mistake in the subs for this film.

entries.meaning: (computing, programming) A subroutine (sometimes one that does not return a value, as distinguished from a function, which does).
examples: The default accessor can be overridden by declaring a sub of the same name in the package.

He was known as 'Mad Carew' by the subs at Khatmandu,He was hotter than they felt inclined to tell;But for all his foolish pranks, he was worshipped in the ranks,And the Colonel's daughter smiled on him as well.

entries.meaning: (colloquial, Internet) A subscription (or (by extension) a subscriber) to an online channel or feed.
examples: I'm totally stoked; just got 10 new subs after my last video.

entries.meaning: (colloquial) Subsistence money: part of a worker's wages paid before the work is finished.

verbs.description: sub (third-person singular simple present subs, present participle subbing, simple past and past participle subbed)

entries.meaning: (US, informal) To work as a substitute teacher, especially in primary and secondary education.
(Britain, informal, soccer) To replace (a player) with a substitute.
examples: He never really made a contribution to the match, so it was no surprise when he was subbed at half time.

entries.meaning: (Britain, informal, soccer) Less commonly, and often as sub on, to bring on (a player) as a substitute.
examples: He was subbed on half way through the second half, and scored within minutes.

entries.meaning: (Britain) To perform the work of a subeditor or copy editor; to subedit.
(slang, Internet, transitive) To subtitle (usually a film or television program).

examples: You've never subbed before. Jessica will be expecting a man on stage that follows orders and enjoys what she's going to be doing. Do you want to be spanked? Possibly whipped?

verbs.description: sub (third-person singular simple present subs, present participle subbing, simple past and past participle subbed)

entries.meaning: To coat with a layer of adhering material; to planarize by means of such a coating.
(microscopy) To prepare (a slide) with a layer of transparent substance to support and/or fix the sample.
examples: Ensure that gloves are worn when handling subbed slides. Although the following protocol describes subbing with gelatin, slides may also be coated with either 3-(triethoxysilyl-)propylamine (TESPA) or poly-L-lysine for in situ hybridization.
